skills.name: Algorithms – Sequences & Patterns
skills.description: Introduction to algorithmic thinking through sequences and patterns

templates.stem: A teacher writes a sequence of numbers on the board. Each number is {diff} more than the previous one. The sequence starts: {a}, {b}, {c}, {d}, ___. What is the next number in the pattern?

A computer program uses a repeat loop to print a greeting. The code says 'repeat {n} [ print 'Hello' ]'. This means the program will print the word 'Hello' ___ times. How many times will 'Hello' appear on the screen?
A programmer needs to write a for loop that counts from 1 to {limit}. The code is: 'for i = 1 to ___ [ print i ]'. What number should replace the blank to make the loop count up to {limit}?
A video game has a scoring system. If a player's score is greater than {threshold}, the program prints 'Pass', otherwise it prints 'Fail'. A player's score is {score}. What will the program print?

A scientist notices that bacteria in a petri dish doubles every hour. Starting with 1 bacterium, after 1 hour there are {mult}, after 2 hours there are {mult2}, and after 3 hours there are {mult3}. If the pattern continues (multiplying by {factor} each time), how many bacteria will there be after 4 hours?

skills.name: Algorithms – Logic & Conditions
skills.description: Boolean logic, conditional statements, and simple program control flow

templates.stem: A website has age restrictions. The program uses conditional logic: if age < {threshold} then display 'child' else display 'teen'. A visitor is {age} years old. What will the website display for this visitor?

A counter program initializes a variable 'count' to 0, then uses a repeat loop: 'count = 0; repeat {n} [ count = count + 1 ]'. This loop adds 1 to count each time it runs. After the loop finishes, what is the final value of count?
In digital circuits, AND gates combine two inputs. An AND gate outputs TRUE only if BOTH inputs are TRUE. If input A = {a} AND input B = {b}, what is the output?
An OR gate is used in computer circuits. An OR gate outputs TRUE if AT LEAST ONE input is TRUE. If input A = {a} OR input B = {b}, what is the output?
A NOT gate is a logic gate that reverses (flips) its input. If the input is TRUE, the output becomes FALSE, and vice versa. If the input = {a}, what is the output of the NOT gate?

skills.name: Algorithms – Functions & Variables
skills.description: Function definitions, variable assignment, iteration, and simple recursion patterns

templates.stem: A programmer defines a function called 'add' that takes two numbers and returns their sum. The function is: 'function add(a, b) returns a + b'. If the programmer calls this function with add({x}, {y}), what value will the function return?

In a program, a variable x stores a number. First, x is assigned the value {initial}. Then the program executes: 'x = x + {increment}'. This takes the current value of x and adds {increment} to it. What is the new value of x?
A programmer writes a simple function: 'function double(n) returns n × 2'. This function takes one input number and multiplies it by 2. If the function is called with double({n}), what is the result?

A loop in a program adds numbers together. The code is: 'for i = 1 to {limit} [ sum = sum + i ]' with sum starting at 0. This loop adds 1, then 2, then 3, and so on up to {limit}. What is the final value of sum?

The Fibonacci sequence is a famous pattern where each number is the sum of the two before it: 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, ___. This sequence is used in algorithms and nature. What is the next number in the Fibonacci sequence after 13?

skills.name: Algorithms – Searching & Sorting
skills.description: Linear and binary search, bubble sort, selection sort, and insertion sort concepts

templates.stem: Linear search checks items one by one to find a value. In a list of {n} items, what is the maximum number of checks needed in the worst case?
Binary search is faster than linear search because it divides the list in half each time. For a list of {n} items, approximately how many checks are needed? (Hint: it's log₂(n))
Bubble sort compares adjacent pairs and swaps them if needed. To sort a list of {n} items completely, approximately how many comparisons are made?
Selection sort finds the minimum element and moves it to the front, then repeats. To sort a list of {n} items, how many times do you repeat this process?
Insertion sort builds a sorted list by inserting one element at a time. If you have {n} unsorted elements, how many elements need to be inserted into the sorted list?

skills.name: Algorithms – Simple Searches & Loops
skills.description: Introduction to simple searching and basic iteration concepts

templates.stem: An algorithm counts from 1 to {n}. How many numbers does it count?
A program checks each item in a list of {n} items one at a time. How many checks does it make?
A loop runs {n} times. Each time it runs, it checks {m} items. How many total checks are made?
To find the biggest number in a list of {n} items, how many comparisons must be made?
A sorting algorithm makes {passes} passes through a list of {n} items. Each pass checks all items. How many total checks?

skills.name: Algorithms – Basic Recursion & Data Structures
skills.description: Introduction to recursion, basic calculations, and simple data structure operations

templates.stem: A recursive factorial function is defined as fact(n) = n × fact(n−1) with fact(0) = 1. How many recursive calls (including the initial call) are made when computing fact({n})?
A recursive function to compute a^n is: pow(n) = a × pow(n−1), pow(0)=1. When computing a^{n}, how many multiplication operations are performed?
A stack starts empty. {push} items are pushed, then {pop} items are popped. How many items remain?
Binary search on a sorted list of {size} items divides the search space in half each step. After {steps} successful divisions, how many items are left to check?
The recursive function solve(n) makes one recursive call on n−{dec} until n ≤ 0. How many calls are made when starting with solve({n})?

skills.name: Algorithms – Paths & Connections
skills.description: Introduction to graphs, connections, and basic path finding

templates.stem: An undirected graph has {v} vertices and each vertex has degree {d}. How many edges does the graph have?
Breadth-First Search (BFS) starts at a node and explores level by level. A node is first reached at level {level}. What is the shortest path length (in edges) from the start node?
A queue starts empty. {add} items are enqueued, then {remove} items are dequeued. How many items remain in the queue?
A complete binary tree of height {h} (root height = 0) has the maximum possible nodes. How many nodes does it contain?
A recursive divide-and-conquer algorithm splits a problem of size {n} into two subproblems of size {n}/2. How many subproblems are created at level 2 of the recursion tree?

skills.name: Algorithms – Optimization & Efficiency
skills.description: Introduction to algorithm optimization, comparing methods, and solving problems efficiently

templates.stem: An algorithm has time complexity 3n² + 5n + 10. For n = {n}, exactly how many operations does it perform?
MergeSort divides an array of size {n} = 2^k until size 1. How many levels of recursion are there (including the base case)?
Quicksort with random pivot has expected O(n log n) comparisons. For n = {n}, approximately how many comparisons are expected (n log₂n, rounded)?
An algorithm runs in O(n³). If n doubles, by what factor does the running time increase?
Binary search runs in O(log n) time. Starting with {start} items, how many times can the search space be halved before ≤ 1 item remains?
